# Arpeggio: 11th in G

## Brief Presentation
An arpeggio is the sounding of the notes of a chord in succession, rather than simultaneously. In this case, the 11th arpeggio in G consists of the notes G, B, D, F#, and A. The 11th arpeggio adds layers of complexity and color to the standard G major chord by including the 11th note, A, in the sequence.

## Notes and Intervals
- G (Root)
- B (Major 3rd)
- D (Perfect 5th)
- F# (Major 7th)
- A (11th/4th)

## Musical Genre and Flavor
The 11th arpeggio in G is often used in jazz, fusion, and contemporary genres to add a more sophisticated and jazzy flavor to the music. The use of the 11th in the arpeggio creates a sense of tension and resolution that can sound complex and harmonically rich.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the 11th arpeggio in G:
1. "Spain" by Chick Corea - This jazz fusion classic features intricate arpeggios and complex chords, including the 11th in G.
2. "So What" by Miles Davis - A modal jazz masterpiece that showcases the 11th arpeggio in G as part of its iconic progression.
3. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock - This jazz standard incorporates the 11th arpeggio in G to create a funky and vibrant harmonic texture.
